ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned what I should expect if I decide to continue with the economics route.
econ
I gained some insights into basic economic concepts and important graphical analysis.
This is just intro micro, so you'll learn all the basics you would in any other similar course.
General introductory economic knowledge: the class focused on the competitive market, production, labor, government intervention, monopoly, and behavioral economics.
I developed a basic understanding of economics and was introduced to a wide variety of real-world applications of the subject.
Knowledge of economics and how the market is structured through supply and demand, production capacity and wages.
I gained immense knowledge in microeconomics and the skill to receive information about a market scenario and be able to analyze it.
Learning to read graphs, solving simple economical questions relating to budget constraints, factors of production, indifference curves, etc.

Gained fundamental understanding in Microeconomic analysis, used quantitative skills and tools to develop microeconomic proficiency, collaborated in a seminar to gain an understanding for the importance of microeconomics in decision making, made real-world connections to what we were learning, and left as a student who knows more about the world.
Intro micro. Very packed class, lots of units covered

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I thought the material was sort of unnecessary and seemed very inapplicable to real-world ideas. However, I am told these are the fundamentals necessary for understanding deeper concepts which can be used.
sometimes became very boring

The lecture slides were relatively unengaging and the lecture style was sometimes repetitive and unhelpful. Concepts were brushed over without much explanation. Tests were fair, though, and the professor clearly did care about the performance of students. She just was not a very engaging lecturer.

The engagement and discussion we could get by learning in a seminar format was great, I'm glad I got to take this course in this format. The worst part to anyone taking this with a strong math background will be how much calculus the course uses while pretending it's not calculus, when it would make infinitely more sense to anyone who'd taken calc 1 to just acknowledge what it was.

Strengths: This course is at its best when the opportunity to collaborate with peers is provided. This occurred many times during class with practice questions and small activities, but could happen much more in the seminar style setting. 

Weaknesses: Lectures can drag and are not recorded for later reference (even though the amount of material on the actual slides is quite minimal).
This course was very strong in that it was very well taught. However, some of the material came across as a bit dry in the lecture setting.
Curve could be less strict
A strength of this course is the material is well-structured and presented in a good sequence.

Strengths: lots of interesting material discussed in class, teacher is very engaging, reading the textbook chapters before class is very helpful 

Weaknesses: not a lot of practice problems other than the weekly problem sets
Very well structured class with great support system

The structure of the class can get boring and repetitive which makes learning at times difficult and challenging. The PSETs and exams were selected appropriately to promote effective learning outcomes. The Teaching Fellow provided a lot of help and guidance outside of the classroom setting.

Strengths: well organized class, a lot of content, most classes were pretty engaging with Professor Simon's dry humor. Weekly psets were not too much work. I especially enjoyed the buzz group parts of class, where we had to talk to our peers and justify what we thought was the answer for an edge-case/special example question that forced us to try to understand the concept.

Weaknesses: high curve and much more a leminar than a seminar. I only know the names of a few peers in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not because it was a very boring course. I would encourage them to take the big lecture.
Yes, the curve is hard but it is very interesting.
sure
Not really unless you have to  but then again, I haven't heard that many of the other ECON 110 sections are any better.
Yes! It's a good course for learning how to understand the decision making that shapes the world around you.

This course is totally worth it for anyone looking to learn more about simple economic theory and practice. It goes much deeper than an AP course on microeconomics would, so its a great stepping stone for harder econ classes at yale.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student; it is interesting and provides a basic understanding of an important subject.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I especially appreciated how the course was taught as a seminar, which made it very easy to ask questions during class, which REALLY helps in understanding the material properly.

Yesit provides a good basic overview for economics. While it is intellectually challenging, it is no overly so. The PowerPoint slides combined with the professors lecture style does put an emphasis on taking notes (and not participating as much), but this format ultimately makes it easier to study in the long run.
This class showed me that I was not interested in economics, so if you are interested or are considering economics take the class.
Yes. Microeconomics helps you become a clear thinker and it's easy to see its many real-world applications.

Yes: Professor Simons is a great intro econ professor and covers some justifications/rational before teaching the topic. She tied in interesting economists, case studies, and good econ books, as well as some of her own anecdotes. Albeit not a seminar, the size of the class is still smaller than the big 115 lecture and does give the advantage that you're sitting closer to the professor and you feel less inhibition in asking questions!
